\begin{abstract}

The prediction of material-specific properties of superconducting systems
such as the electronic structure and the transition temperature
is one of the major challenge in modern solid-state physics.
In this paper we present the first material specific calculations
of realistic superconductor -- normal metal heterostructures using density functional theory.
In particular, we calculate the quasiparticle spectrum of different normal metal overlayers on a Nb(100) host.
We find that the Andreev reflection leads to the formation of momentum dependent quasiparticle bands in the normal metal.
As a consequence, the spectrum has a strongly momentum dependent induced gap.
From the thickness dependence of the gap size we calculate the superconducting critical temperature
of Au/Nb(100) heterostructures where we find very good agreement with experiments. Moreover, predictions are
made for similar heterostructures of other compounds.
\end{abstract}


\maketitle






Modern material science now allows to produce thin film  materials
that consists  of several layers of various metals, in a way that some of these layers may become superconductors at low enough temperatures
~\cite{Yamazaki1, Yamazaki2, Ferrier}.
Such artificial composite materials are called superconductor-metal heterostructures, and their importance lies in the fact that
every superconducting device, for the foreseeable future, will have to interface with normal metals, which
carries power to it. These structures are also an ideal testing grounds for theories of low-dimensional superconductivity, which may
later become the basis of new devices and sensors. Therefore it is extremely important to understand the physics behind such interfaces,
to make them more suitable for a given purpose.

One of the key experiment~\cite{Yamazaki1, Yamazaki2} in the study of superconductor-metal heterostructures was carried out on
an extremely thin layer of gold grown on top of a thicker Nb host.
In this experiment, while the thickness of the Nb sample (288~{\AA}) was in the order of the superconducting coherence length (380~{\AA}),
the gold overlayer was only a couple of atomic layers thick.
In order to investigate the superconducting properties of
such bilayers, magnetization and magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed using a
superconducting quantum interference device magnetometer~(SQUID)~\cite{Yamazaki2}.
It was found that the superconducting transition temperature is significantly lowered in this composite
compared to the bulk, and it decays monotonically as the thickness of the gold overlayer increases.

The explanation of the above experiment poses a great challenge to theory because the standard theory of superconductivity, the BCS theory,
does not describe inhomogeneous systems easily.
However such systems can be treated efficiently in terms of the Bogoliubov-de Gennes (BdG) equations~\cite{Bogo,deGennes}, 
which recently has been extended to a more material specific form~\cite{Luders1,Luders2,Csire} leading to the so called Kohn-Sham-Bogoliubov-deGennes (KS-BdG) equations.
In principle these equations are able to describe systems with inhomogeneities in the pairing potential closely related
to the superconducting gap $\Delta$.

Several theoretical studies on various model systems showed that in such inhomogeneous systems like multilayers,
it is possible to find bound quasiparticle states which are a coherent mixture of electron and hole states.
These states have been found theoretically in superconductor -- normal metal -- superconductor
heterostructures~\cite{Andreev66} and in other systems as well~\cite{deGennes63,Caroli}.
The Andreev reflection~\cite{Andreev64} has been identified as the key effect which
leads to the formation of such bound states, often referred to as Andreev bound states:
in a semiclassical approximation, an electron with energy lying in the superconducting gap, arriving from the normal metal to the
interface is retro-reflected as a hole and a Cooper pair is formed with an electron of opposite spin in the superconductor.
Although the properties of Andreev bound states became an intensively studied research field~\cite{Fuechsle,Pillet,Dirks,Bretheau,Mayaffre},
their material specific dispersion, namely their band structure, has never been calculated (nor observed experimentally) to date.
Our aim in this paper is to make up for this deficiency in the theory and calculate the dispersion relation of Andreev states.
We also verify that this effect enables the transport of supercurrents through non-superconducting materials, and
is the key to predict the superconducting transition temperature in the whole system.

In what follows we numerically solve the  above mentioned KS-BdG equations, as it was described in Ref.~\cite{Csire}, for an 
Au/Nb(100) overlayer system.
For varying Au thicknesses we calculate the quasiparticle electronic structure and obtain the superconducting gap for each thickness.
Finally a method is developed to calculate the critical temperature.








The first step down this road is to construct a realistic model of the interface lattice structure.
Such a model can be built up from two-dimensional translational invariant atomic layers as follows.
We divide the system into three regions: (i) a semi-infinite bulk (Nb); (ii) the interface region
that -- in our case -- consists of six superconducting layers (Nb), various number of normal metal layers and
three layers of empty spheres; (iii) and a semi-infinite vacuum.
Although the thickness of the Nb layers in the experiment is not strictly semi-infinite, it is thick enough to be 
approximated by a semi-infinite bulk system. We use six Nb layers to mimic the transition between the semi-infinite bulk and the 
overlayer. The Nb has the body-centered cubic (bcc) crystal structure with a lattice parameter of $a = 3.3$~\AA.
We assume the realistic face-centered cubic (fcc) crystal structure for the gold overlayers, and the termination of the material layers are
modeled by a semi-infinite vacuum. We also neglect imperfections at the interface, like interlayer relaxations and intermixing.

In such systems, where translational invariance is preserved only parallel to the interface, the quasiparticle spectrum  is obtained
as a function of a two dimensional momentum vector $\vec{k}_{||}$ . To visualize this spectrum, it is customary to calculate the Bloch spectral function (BSF).
A three dimensional purely electronic system would result in a BSF which is a delta function every time when $\varepsilon$
and $\vec{k}$ form a band. In two dimensionally translational invariant systems this is not always the case,
and the BSF for layer $I$ is defined as
$A_B^I(\varepsilon, \vec{k}_{||})= -\frac{1}{\pi} \mathrm{Im} G_{II}(\varepsilon,\vec{k}_{||})$,
where $G_{II}$ is the layer projected Green function (see Ref.~\cite{Csire}).
However, the integral of the BSF over the 2D Brillouin zone still gives the density of states in a layer resolved way.
Since the BSF is equivalent to the quasiparticle spectrum, drawing a contour plot of
the BSF as a function of energy along specified directions of $\vec{k}_{||}$ is a powerful tool to visualize the quasiparticle states.
Evidently, in a layered system this contour plot can be done for each layer.

In order to understand the quasiparticle spectrum in the superconducting state better, let us first perform a calculation 
just in the normal state, by simply solving the Schr\"{o}dinger equation for the
Au/Nb(001) overlayer system. In Fig.~\ref{fig:normal1} we show the contour plot of the BSF
for a layer that we considered to be in the "middle" of the samples of various Au layer thicknesses.
The plots are restricted in energy to the range of [-0.05~Ry,0.05~Ry] (later we will choose
${\Delta}_{Nb}$, the superconducting gap to equal this value, and solve the BdG equations within this energy range).
When Fig.~\ref{fig:normal1} viewed as a sequence, one can immediately recognize the signatures of
quantum confinement. For energies where the DOS in the bulk Nb is low, the states in the Au are confined, as they can not scatter into the Nb,
and on the other side the system is limited by vacuum. In regions where the DOS is high in the Nb, the states in the Au
are smeared out, as here the electrons can scatter more easily into the other side of the interface. The confined states
in the Au, therefore, can be regarded as quantum-well (QW) states.

Now let us consider the Nb in the superconducting state and solve the first-principles BdG equations as
described in Ref.~\cite{Csire}. In this formalism each layer is characterized by an additional, potential-like parameter,
the  superconducting gap ${\Delta}$. To solve
the BdG equation we will assume that all Nb layers show the same superconducting gap ${\Delta}_{Nb}=0.05$~Ry. This is a much larger value
than the gap observed experimentally, in order to make it easier to visualize the quasiparticle spectrum. We also assume, that the
superconducting gap is zero in the Au layers, namely we set ${\Delta}_{Au}=0.0$Ry, as Au is not superconducting at all in the bulk.

Based on the symmetry of the BdG equations it is known, that in bulk superconductors the quasiparticle states can be obtained
from the electronic states by mirroring the band structure of the normal state to the Fermi energy and opening up a gap.
In the case of our inhomogeneous system the situation is entirely different, and the main question is how  the niobium host affects 
the quasiparticle spectrum of the gold overlayers.
In Fig.~\ref{fig:supra_band} we plot the BSF summed for all Au layers in the case of different number of gold layers
(left hand side of the figure).
To illustrate the role of the crystal structure, on the right hand side of the figure we also show results of the same calculations 
performed by assuming bcc Au layers throughout the overlayer. This is not entirely unrealistic for very thin layers but most 
likely artificial for thicker ones, where the Au layers
most certainly grow in an fcc structure. Unfortunately there is very little known of the crystal structures of thin Au layers on Nb.

We can immediately see from Fig.~\ref{fig:supra_band}, that the proximity of a superconductor
in the studied heterostructures induces the expected mirroring of the electronic bands, and additionally opens up a
gap at each band crossing.
One can also see from the figure that the size of the induced gap in the gold is strongly $\vec{k}_{||}$-dependent,
and it is the same for all layers, however, it decreases as function of the thickness of the gold overlayers.
It should be noted as well that those regions of the spectrum which were more or less smeared out in the normal state
(visualized in the figure by weaker lines) now sharpened up.
This is the consequence of the opening of the superconducting gap in the Nb: the states where scattering
into was allowed before, now disappeared because of the gap.
We can also conclude from the figure that the quantum-well states, which we found to exist in the normal state band structure calculations,
become bound Andreev states originating from the Andreev scattering at the interface.
Finally, since Fig.~\ref{fig:supra_band} was obtained by summing up $A_B^I(\varepsilon, \vec{k}_{||})$, and this sum does not show any significant
broadening, it is clear that the quasiparticle spectrum is virtually identical in every interfacial layer.
In Fig.~\ref{fig:supra_band} one can also observe changes in the quasiparticle spectrum owing to different lattice structures.
In particularly, more `oscillations' can be seen in fcc gold overlayers compared to the bcc ones,
which is the consequence of the more bands of the fcc gold in the normal state.
Also, there is a very sharp, almost  horizontal band in the case of bcc gold, which originates from the interface layers only.
This interface state does not appear in the case of fcc gold, so while its appearance is rather interesting, it is entirely fictitious.
